data.text: IDENTIFICATION AND MANAGEMENT OF PATIENTS  CLINICAL GUIDELINES WITH MENTAL ILL HEALTH DURING THE PERINATAL  Register no: 09090 PERIOD  Status: Public

data.text: Document History:
INDEX
This guideline is to increase the professional knowledge and awareness of the significance of perinatal mental illness by highlighting the risks to childbearing women and their families.
To provide guidance for professionals on the method of screening and early recognition of women at high risk of moderate to severe mental illness during the perinatal period .
To ensure there is an appropriate referral system to evoke effective plans of care and support strategies.

To promote and encourage inter-professional communications working across organisations to ensure practitioners provide individualised evidence based care tailored for the needs of women with mental health issues.
To provide guidance to professionals enabling them to identify vulnerability and risk factors in a family unit that may predict a woman's predisposition to mental illness in the perinatal period.
Equality and Diversity
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to provision of a service that is fair, accessible, and meets the needs of all individuals.
Background

The latest confidential enquiry into Maternal and Child Health identified mental illness as has an implication in a growing number of maternal deaths. Deaths from suicide remain a leading cause of maternal death in pregnancy and during the first year of the postnatal period. Sixty-seven women, new mothers included died from psychiatric related causes during the antenatal period and within a year of delivery, with 29 of these deaths attributed to suicide. The description of these deaths highlights the significant impact that ongoing mental health problems have on maternal health (CEMACH, 2011).

Mental health problems are a major cause of ill health and childbirth represents a particularly vulnerable time for women's mental health. Mental illness associated with child birth is common, both for new episodes specifically related to childbirth and for the recurrence of pre-existing conditions.

Maternal mental health disorder during pregnancy and the postnatal period can have serious consequences for women, their newborn and entire family. Perinatal mental health disorder has the potential to negatively affect the care provided by a mother to her child which results in adverse effect on the child's wellbeing and later emotional and behavioural development. Women suffering from moderate to severe mental health disorder have been noted to have higher incidence of physical morbidity and poor obstetric outcome such as neonatal stillbirth, premature delivery and small for gestational age babies

Ten percent of mothers are likely to experience some degree of depressive illness in the postnatal year with 3-5% suffering from a severe depressive illness. Two women in 1000 will require admission with puerperal psychosis. Women who have had a past episode of severe mental illness following delivery have a 1:2 to 1:3 chance of reoccurrence.
Purpose
Introduction

Evidence suggests that early diagnosis with effective care pathways involving multi disciplinary team collaboration can prevent worsening conditions and enhance the opportunity for favourable outcomes (CEMACH 2011).

It is therefore important that women who are at risk are identified early and receive effective multidisciplinary care from the obstetric and mental heath team. The named midwife has a vital role to play in the process of ensuring appropriate referral and planning of care. The named Midwife has to liaise with the Perinatal Specialist Midwife in drawing out a tailor made care package beneficial to the specific needs of the women.

An interpreter is to be provided for all non English speaking women. Family members should not be mainly relied upon as interpreters as it can prevent women from disclosing vital information that may be significant to their care.
(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Interpreting and Translation Policy'; register number 09127A)
Key Professionals

The provision of care to women with mental health needs during the perinatal period requires the collaborative involvement of the multidisciplinary team in the care of the woman and to work closely with the woman and family. The multidisciplinary team involved throughout the child bearing process includes the following:
GP
Health Visitor
Specialist midwife for mental health
Named Midwife
Obstetrician
Mental Health Team
It may also include:
Children and Young People's Services
Lead Midwife for Safeguarding (if safeguarding issues)

This guideline provides guidance for all staff on the method of screening and identification of mental health disorders and acts as a care pathway in line with national guidelines. This guideline is supported by standards set out in the NICE guideline (2007), recommendations from the CEMACH (2011) report, Good practice standards from the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG) (2011) and clinical risk management standards of NHS Litigation Authority.

It applies to all staff working within hospital and community settings (including registered and non registered staff) who provide care or provide information to women and their families during the Antenatal and Postnatal period.
Management during the Antenatal Period

Healthcare professionals should ensure women are seen for their first antenatal booking appointment by 12 completed weeks of pregnancy, in order to facilitate the process for early identification of women at high risk of major mental illness.

Assessment – at the woman's first contact with services; healthcare professionals (including midwives, obstetricians, health visitors and General Practitioner) should undertake the woman's assessment in a sensitive and careful systematic way. Enquiry from all women should include a detailed history of their previous psychiatric history. This is to enable professionals to identify patients with previous mental disorder and to identify those at risk of severe mental health disorders. Care should be taken to ascertain the severity and clinical presentation of any previous episode and the treatment received.

6.2.1  The patient's current psychotropic medication should be recorded and dosage clearly written in the antenatal notes. It should be noted that sodium valproate – used as a mood stabiliser - is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the substantial increased risk of major congenital malformations (prevalence 11%) and developmental delay (prevalence 40%) in exposed infants. In such cases, women should consider using safer alternatives such as anti-psychotics.
At the booking appointment: First contact with Midwife/GP/Obstetrician the following screening questions should be discussed with the woman:
6.3.1 Screening Questions (Phase 1)
Question1: Do you have or have you had a severe mental illness in the past? This
includes the following;
Schizophrenia
Bipolar Disorder
Severe depression
Postnatal Traumatic stress Disorder
Obsessive Compulsive Disorder
Severe eating disorder
Self Harm
Suicidal Behaviour
Psychosis in the postnatal period
6.3.2 Question 2: Have you had previous treatment by a psychiatrist/specialist mental health team including inpatient care, crisis resolution team, community mental health team?
6.3.3 Question 3: Do you have a family history of Perinatal Mental Illness and or severe Mental illness?

6.3.4 If the patient answers ‘yes' to any of the above questions, discuss further with her to ascertain the severity, duration and current/previous treatment received and document legibly in the healthcare records and include all details on all referral forms. One third to one half of patients with a past history of mental health issues will experience a recurrence.

6.3.5 Patients should also be asked in a sensitive manner about any history of intimate partner violence, sexual abuse or assault, the use of illegal drugs, and the lack of social support, as it is these groups of women that are at risk of depressive illness and prone to suicide in pregnancy
Identification Questions or Whooley Questions (Phase 2)

6.4.1 This second phase of screening in accordance to NICE (2007) recommendation is to assist professionals to identify patients with current mental health disorder or at risk of developing mainly depression and this may be achieved with a specific set of questions known as the Whooley questions.

6.4.2 At the woman's first contact with primary care, at her booking visit, midwives should ask the following two questions to identify possible depression after the first set of history questions have been asked and discussed. Midwives should document that the Whooley questions have been asked and record the response in the health care records:
During the past month, have you often been bothered by feeling down, depressed or hopeless?
During the past month, have you often been bothered by having little interest or pleasure in doing things?
6.4.3 A third question should be considered if the patient answers yes to either of the initial questions.
Is this something you need or want help with?
(Refer to Appendix C for risk factors and features of mental health illness)
Screening for Anxiety Disorder using the 2-item Generalized Anxiety Disorder Scale (Phase 3)
6.5.1 This third phase of screening is a recommendation from NICE (2014) for Professionals to consider asking about anxiety using a recommended 2-item screening scale.
Following the identification questions (Whooley questions) midwives are to ask the the woman about anxiety and record her response in her handheld records:
During the past month, have you been feeling nervous, anxious or on edge?
During the past month have you not been able to stop or control worrying?

At every subsequent antenatal appointment a continuing risk assessment of the patient's mental health should be made by all Professionals. The emphasis should be on the clinical signs of depression or impaired mental health. On identifying any mental health concerns the health care professional should offer the appropriate form of care and support tailored to the needs of the woman (refer to appendix A). This plan of care offered should be documented in the health care records.

The term ‘postnatal depression' (PND) should be used with caution as it can be used too broadly giving the impression that it term was a less severe diagnosis than it actually was. It should be used only to describe a non-psychotic depressive illness of mild to moderate severity with its onset following delivery. It should not be used as a generic term to describe other mental illness. The CEMACH (2007) report highlights of cases of maternal deaths where a past illness was recorded as PND, despite evidence of a severe psychiatric illness.

The midwife should liaise with the GP, health visitor, community psychiatric nurse (CPN) or link worker to confirm the severity of previous illness where possible. Patients may under report illness due to a fear of stigma and concerns over child protection.

It is also important to ask generally about the patient's wellbeing at each antenatal visit; further enquiry may follow if issues are raised. The significance of other problems for example domestic abuse, relationship problems and sleep patterns should also be considered as they impact on the mental wellbeing of a person.
Health professionals must also be aware of the “normal” emotional experiences relating to pregnancy so as not to ignore or misdiagnose depression.
Referral and Initial Care
At booking, where the midwife identifies mental health problems, the midwife should develop an individual management plan and record in the health care records.

When a patient reports mental illness, an enquiry should be made, in a sensitive manner as to its severity, clinical presentation, treatment, and timing of onset and duration. Details of involvement with other agencies i.e. psychiatrist should be taken with contact details as required. Correct documentation of this information in the health care records of this information is paramount.

All patients identified with current or past history of moderate/severe mental disorders, including those with current or past history of moderate mental disorders and on medication, should be referred to the Lead Midwife for Perinatal Mental ill Health's clinic at 16 weeks or later if booked after 16 weeks (Refer to appendix B).

Patients who have a current or past history of a moderate/severe psychiatric disorder and who also have medical and obstetric related risk factors, should be seen by their own Obstetric Consultant in the form of shared care between the Obstetric Consultant and Lead Midwife Perinatal Mental ill Health.

Patients with a past or present history of a minor mental health problem should be referred initially to their GP to decide on further management and be offered continuity of care from the hospital and community team. All Health Professionals should liaison with the specialist midwife for mental health for planning and management of care for women with mild mental disorders.
Patients who are currently under the care of psychiatric services should be referred back to their own consultant in the first instance for review and also to the specialist midwife
for mental health. Patients who require psychiatric assessment and do not have their
own psychiatrist should be referred to the community mental health Team immediately
to be seen within one month of first contact with services.

The Lead Midwife Perinatal Mental ill Health should be notified about all pregnant and postnatal patients with identified history of mental health disorder who fall outside the set criteria. (Refer to Appendix B)
The Lead Midwife Perinatal Mental ill Health should also be notified of all patients admitted to the psychiatric/mother and baby unit in Mid-Essex.

There should be a close liaison between all involved health professionals to ensure an effective plan of care is developed and agreed, which includes a clear referral pathway via the yellow vulnerable women alert form, which can be implemented immediately in the event of a psychiatric episode during the perinatal period. (Refer to Appendix E)

This should take the form of a pre-birth planning meeting at 32 weeks gestation involving the prospective parents. There should be an agreed plan of action by all professionals involved in the patient's care including plan of care for the postnatal period, for example
frequency of visiting. This must include liaison with the mental health team. This plan should be documented in health care records. It should also be recorded that such a meeting has occurred.

Introduction of the Rainbow Mother and Baby Unit to the patient during the antenatal period should be considered as a means of parallel planning towards the management of her care. Where there are safeguarding issues this meeting should include the Lead midwife for safeguarding, Lead Midwife Perinatal Mental ill Health and named social worker.

Every patient with past or current history of mental disorder should have a named midwife who they see regularly to ensure continuity of care and to enable any deterioration in mental health to be identified promptly and acted upon.

Mental health disorders do not automatically require a referral to the Child and Family (C&F) Team (Social Services), although this should always be considered. Patients who are fully supported, accepting of services and leading a normal life may not present any risk to the baby's safety.

Ongoing assessment throughout the pregnancy should be in place as previously stated, and referral to the C&F Team can of course be arranged at any time, should there be any deterioration in maternal health giving rise to concerns for the baby's safety.

The named midwife for safeguarding should also be notified of any patient with current severe mental disorders and copied into all FORS (Family Operations Request for Support) (social care) referrals. Midwives with such women on their caseload are responsible for accessing Safeguarding Supervision as per the policy.

Women who decline referral to specialist midwife for mental health and community mental health team should be encouraged to engage with the specialist midwife and mental health services. The woman's individual needs and preferences must be taken into account. They should be offered the opportunity to make informed decision about their care and treatment with the support of healthcare professionals.
If the patient however declines referral to the above services, the midwife or health professional discussing the referral process with the patient should:
Discuss the risk associated with non engagement with mental health services and the risk associated with relapse in the perinatal period
Highlight the benefits of adequate management of mental health disorder with the support of professionals
Enquire whether the patient is willing to engage with professionals already known to her such as her GP
Refer the patient to the GP and Link Obstetric Consultant for Mental Health so her risk of relapse can be addressed
A discussion between the midwife/Health professional and the GP/Obstetric Consultant about plan of care must take place to ensure the woman receives the appropriate care

Conduct a risk assessment to ascertain if there is a risk to the woman herself or to the newborn, in that case the above step must be followed and also referral to Children and Young people's services (social services) must be made.
Intrapartum Management
Review the patient's healthcare and medical records on admission for identified mental health issues and to obtain information on any psychosocial intervention in the woman's care.
Follow the individual management plan agreed in the patient's healthcare records.
Midwives should note whether the patient is known to Children and Families Social Services and notify the relevant personnel of the patient's admission.
Ensure appropriate information is cascaded when the patient is transferred between wards.
The Lead Midwife Perinatal Mental ill Health can be contacted if any support is required by the Labour Ward Co-ordinator or midwife in caring for the patient in labour.
All prescribed antidepressants or antipsychotic medication should be administered at prescribed times unless stated otherwise in the patient's care plan.

In the event of sudden onset of disturbing behaviour or concerning changes in mental state staff must seek urgent psychiatric review from the Crisis Team. The Lead Midwife Perinatal Mental ill Health should also be contacted if within working hours for support.
Postnatal Management

Educational support for patients with mental health issues (or patients prone to develop mental disorders) is important in the perinatal period especially the immediate days, weeks and months post delivery. Educational support is thus needed in areas such as breastfeeding, neonatal sleep patterns, adjustment to new parental role, and coping strategies with newborn during the early postnatal period, benefits/financial support and contraception.

Midwives, Health Visitors and other health care professionals instrumental in the postnatal care of the patient should provide such educational support to enable mothers and their families to make informed choices. Health professionals should also signpost patients and their families to the relevant services for support.
There are 3 main types of postnatal emotional events. The table below describes these and outlines appropriate care for each.

table_items.text: Usually occurs between days 3 - 10 post birth
1/4 of cases occur in first month postnatal, Lasts for 3+ months. Usually resolves within 1 year.
95% occurs before 4 weeks. 65% occurs before 2 weeks
10 - 15% of women. Risk of recurrence in 30-50%.
Usually none, however if tearfulness is ongoing, the midwife should refer the mother to her GP and notify
Aim to achieve continuity of care by the same midwife for the antenatal and postnatal periods &
In the community, the CRISIS Team would need to be called and an immediate visit requested so an assessment can be made and a rapid

the Specialist midwife for mental health and Health Visitor. Care should be individualised for the woman to incorporate her needs. Reassurance and support networks should be implemented. The woman should be fully informed when the midwife is to transfer care to the other members of the primary care team e.g. GP and health visitor

seamless hand-over to health visitor. Refer to Specialist midwife mental health. Recognise deviations from the normal e.g. extreme sleep deprivation, as possible warning signs Refer to GP; consider use of appropriate medication Good listening and counselling skills essential Consider use of self-help & support groups e.g. National Childbirth Trust (NCT), Homestart. May need involvement of mental health care team

referral to psychiatric specialist can be initiated. If the midwife is present, she needs to stay with the woman and family until a plan of care has been initiated e.g. the woman and her baby admitted to a mother and baby unit. Alert the Specialist Midwife for Mental Health for support and input. In hospital, midwives must alert the specialist midwife for mental health immediately for support and input (if out of working hours the bleep holder) and refer to the obstetric team who should make an urgent referral to the on-call psychiatric team via the CRISIS Team

data.text: Immediate period post delivery: on admitting the mother and baby to the Postnatal ward, the receiving midwife on the postnatal ward has a responsibility to ascertain whether the patient has a perinatal mental health care plan/ safeguarding alert care plan and should ensure that the recommendations for that patient's care are well communicated to all staff at handover to ensure that the plan is adhered to.

Midwives, obstetricians, neonatologists and all professionals involved in providing the postnatal care should read the patient's healthcare records carefully in order to be knowledgeable about any previous and planned interventions in relation to the patient's care to include:

All recommendations made in relation to the care of mother and baby should be adhered to by all professionals. Mother and baby are not to be discharged from hospital until the recommendations and plan of care have been implemented. A pre-discharge planning meeting with relevant professionals instrumental in the care of patient and family may be required before discharge

All prescribed medications with details documented in the care plan should be administered by qualified staff at prescribed times. If medications are not prescribed the midwife should contact the duty obstetric SHO to prescribe in accordance with the care plan
Recommendation for breastfeeding documented in the care plan should be adhered to and patients who can breastfeed safely while on their medication should be supported to do so

All professionals including maternity support workers must observe the patient's behaviour and interaction with the infant and record in the postnatal notes. In the case of concerns noted around this area or other areas (in relation to the woman's suspected inability to adequately care for the infant due to her mental state), a referral to Social Service's Children and Young People Team may become vital and a discussion with the Lead midwife for safeguarding becomes necessary
Patients who require psychiatric admission following childbirth should be admitted to the Rainbow mother and baby unit together with their infant

Liaison with all health professionals is essential; especially in line with the community midwives and health visiting services whereby the professionals concerned should be directly informed of each individual case.
Acute Episode

If the midwife/obstetrician suspects that a patient may be experiencing an acute mental health episode i.e. puerperal psychosis, the patient should be kept under constant observation until appropriate assessments can be made. Wherever possible this observation should be by a member of the midwifery team.
Safety of the patient and her baby is paramount. It may be appropriate to insist that the baby to be cared for by a family member.
Ward staff should urgently request the on call obstetric registrar to physically assess the patient and exclude any other causes.

Ward staff should seek urgent psychiatric referral and assessment by contacting the CRISIS team and alerting the Lead Midwife Perinatal Mental ill Health. In referring patients to the CRISIS Team for urgent review, professionals must clearly state the concerns and insist on a psychiatric opinion and review of the patient urgently. Refer to the next senior member of the obstetric team or contact the bleep holder or the Supervisor of Midwives if difficulties arise in gaining psychiatric opinions and support from the relevant professionals. (Refer to Appendix D)

A multi disciplinary team management plan should be made. This should include the ‘best' place to care for the woman and her baby with the appropriate nursing care and a level of surveillance. The Rainbow Unit may be useful to prevent a separation of mother from baby.

If the professional feels that there is any danger to the patient herself, her baby or the health care professional it may be appropriate to seek additional support i.e. police, social services or the Crisis Team and involve all relevant professionals for support and appropriate management of care in such crucial situations.

The Lead Midwife Perinatal Mental ill Health should be notified by the Labour Ward Co- ordinator of all women who have either relapsed or developed postpartum psychosis and therefore required emergency review from either the Crisis Team or from their psychiatrist on the ward.
Discharge Process
All professionals instrumental in the care of the woman should be notified of the birth and discharge of the mother and baby from hospital to her discharge location
If a psychiatric review is needed before discharge (should be documented in care plan) midwives should ensure this takes place before discharge.
The Lead Midwife Perinatal Mental ill Health should be informed of all patients
transferred from the Postnatal Ward or Broomfield Hospital to the Rainbow Unit or the
Linden Centre or any other private psychiatric hospital.

A copy of the patient's care plan must be sent to the community midwives and health visitor including other community midwifery services that are responsible for the provision of postnatal care for out-of-area women. In addition the GP should also be sent details of the discharge process and a copy of the care plan
Community Care

Community midwives should contact the patient's allocated Health Visitor and discuss any identified issues during the antenatal, intrapartum and early postnatal period and request for early involvement of the Health Visitor's care.

All patients with previous and current mental health disorders should be offered enhanced postnatal visits by the community midwives up to 28 days post delivery. Frequency of these visits should be offered to women on an individual basis; and only daily within the first 10 days for high risk women with previous or current moderate to severe mental health disorder. The first 10 days for other women with previous or current mild mental health issues should consist of routine selective visits for the st 10 days then once weekly ‘listening visits' for support.
Community midwives and maternity support workers should continue to assess the
patient's mental health and should consider referral to either GP or community mental

health Team (following a discussion with the GP) if any concerning changes are noted. Midwives should familiarise themselves with knowledge about signs of relapse and the method of responding to emergency psychiatric situations through care pathway.

Effective communication between midwives and multidisciplinary teams must frequently take place so as to enhance effective tailoring to the individual patient and baby's need and also to ensure the safeguarding of children.
Patients with previous and current mental health disorders must be given continuity of
care by a named community midwife to promote the early identification of mental health issues and prompt referral of psychiatric services.
Staffing and Training

All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills training. The Lead Midwife Perinatal Mental ill Health will provide training for all staff (registered and non-registered) who are instrumental in the care of women during the perinatal period. The training will be centred on early identification, preventative measures and management of mental disorders in the perinatal period.

Healthcare professionals have the responsibility of ensuring they book themselves onto the training so as to be proficient in addressing mental health disorders when providing care for these vulnerable clients.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.
As a minimum the following specific requirements must include a description of the:
Process for identifying women during the antenatal period who have a current mental health problem, or who are at risk of developing a mental health problem
Process for identifying women who are at risk of developing a mental health problem or exacerbating a pre-existing mental illness during the postnatal period
Documentation of an individual management plan where appropriate Process for the documentation of clear lines of communication between the maternity service and the following:

A review of a suitable sample of health records of patients to include the minimum requirements as highlighted in point 16.2 will be audited. A minimum compliance 75% is required for each requirement. Where concerns are identified more frequent audit will be undertaken.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge and skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most recently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.

Guideline monitors have been nominated to each clinical area to ensure a system whereby obsolete guidelines are archived and newly approved guidelines are now downloaded from the intranet and filed appropriately in the guideline folders. ‘Spot checks' are performed on all clinical guidelines quarterly.

Quarterly Clinical Practices group meetings are held to discuss ‘guidelines'. During this meeting the practice development midwife can highlight any areas for further training; possibly involving ‘workshops' or to be included in future ‘skills and drills' mandatory training sessions.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued and available to all staff including an update on the latest ‘guidelines' information such as a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Focus Magazine that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.

Regular memos are posted on the guideline notice boards in each clinical area to notify staff of the latest revised guidelines and how to access guidelines via the intranet or clinical guideline folders.
References
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (2014) Antenatal and postnatal mental health: clinical management and service guidance. NICE Clinical Guideline (CG192) London: NICE
Available at: https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg192

Boyd, R.C. and Worley, H. (2007) Utility of the Postpartum Depression Screening Scale among Low-Income Ethnic Minority Women. In: Rosenfield, A (2006) New research in postpartum depression. Nova Science Publishers.
Bonari, L., N., Ahn, E et al (2004) Perinatal risks of untreated depression during pregnancy. Canadian journal of psychiatry. 49(11): 726-735.
Beck, C. And Gable R. (2000) Postpartum Depression Screening Scale, Development and psychometric testing. Nursing Research 49(5): 272-282
Confidential Enquiries into Maternal Deaths (2011) Saving Mother's Lives; Reviewing Maternal Deaths to Make Motherhood Safer: 2006-2008 London, Wiley- Blackwell.
Confidential Enquiries into Maternal Deaths (2007) Saving Mother's Lives; Reviewing Maternal Deaths to Make Motherhood Safer: 2003-2005 London, Wiley- Blackwell.
Hanna, B., Jarman, H., Savage, S. and Layton K. (2004) The Early Detection of Postpartum Depression: Midwives and Nurses Trial a Checklist.
JOGNN: Journal of Obstetric, Gynecologic & Neonatal Nursing 33(2): 191-197
Howard, L. (2005) Fertility and Pregnancy in women with psychotic disorders. European journal of obstetrics Gynaecology and Reproductive Biology. 119(1):3-10
Khalifeh H.(2015) Safety of psychotropic drugs in pregnancy. British Medical Journal 350: h2260

Osborn, D. P. J., Levy, G., Nazareth, J et al (2007) Relative risk of cardiovascular and cancer mortality in people with severe mental illness from the United Kingdom's General Practice Research Database. Archives of General Psychiatry. 64(2): 242-249

Stein, A.T., Malmberg, L., Sylva, K., Barnes, J. and Leach, P.S (2008) The influence of maternal depression, caregiving, and socioeconomic status in the post-natal year on children's language development Child: Care, Health and Development 34(5) p.603-612
Thomas, D. (2011) Maternity Clinical Practice Guideline: Women with Antenatal and Postnatal mental health issues. London, Homerton University hospital.

With thanks to Dona Thomas: Specialist midwife for mental Health Homerton University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust and Homerton University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust for their permission to adapt their maternal mental Health Policy in reviewing this guideline.
Care Pathway for Patients with Moderate to Severe Mental Health Issues
SCREENING STAGE – 1ST VISIT
STEP 1: IDENTIFICATION QUESTIONS
Each professional should ask once (1st contact) & record in woman's healthcare records.

data.text: Provide enhanced/ extended postnatal care (28 days with daily visits st  days for women with history of moderate/severe mental disorders and those with current symptoms).
Early contact by the Health Visitor.
Maintain effective communication between professionals involved in the woman's care.
In the case of psychiatric emergency refer to care pathway.
Refer to children centres and outreach worker to promote involvement in therapeutic
activities/groups

data.text: Risk Factors and Recognition

table_items.text: Previous history of mood disorder. Family history of severe mood disorder Poor social support Stillbirth or Neonatal Death
Initial features include: Insomnia Irritability Restless agitation Refusal of food
Pre occupations and delusions concerning the baby
Illation and grandiosity are also common
Associated with high morbidity and risk of self-harm or neglect to the baby
Worry about ability to cope with baby

data.text: The significance of other problems should be considered. These may include eating disorders, domestic violence, alcohol and drug abuse and fertility problems
The Rainbow Mother and Baby Unit

data.url: 09090 Mental Ill Health during Perinatal Period 4.0.024.jpeg

data.text: What Does Rainbow mother and Mother Unit Have Offer?
Antenatal and postnatal mental health care for mothers and babies (from birth to 12 months) For mothers with pre-existing mental illness and/or postnatal depression.
The key aims of all activities include:
Stress management
Relaxation
Life style planning and organising
Assertiveness
Managing anger and irritability
Interaction between mums and babies
Building social support networks
Effective time management to create a balance between work, leisure and self maintenance
Suggested Activities
This should not be taken as a definitive list:
Baby massage/Yoga
Post Natal Exercise
Exercise Group
Writing sessions, Diaries, Scrap books
Photography/Video Sessions
Art and Craft, Baby Footprints, Pottery
Swimming Sessions
Computers
Creative Art Activities
Walking Group
gardening
Cookery
Drama
Art Therapy
Dance therapy
Sensory room
Gym
Telephone: 01245 318847/38853 Email: enquiries@nepft.nhs.uk
The Linden Centre, Pudding Wood Lane, Chelmsford Essex, CM17 7LF
